title: Fine-grained Fallacy Detection with Human Label Variation
author: Alan Ramponi (Digital Humanities group, Fondazione Bruno Kessler), Agnese Daffara (Department of Humanities, University of Pavia), Sara Tonelli (Digital Humanities group, Fondazione Bruno Kessler), ...
relevance_why: The methods and datasets proposed for fallacy detection can be applied to enhance text-based argument analysis which has implications in areas like automated dialogue systems and misinformation detection, useful in audio-to-text relations.
background: The task involves detecting various types of fallacies in social media posts through segment-level analysis, providing a new data resource for evaluating argumentation in public discourse.
contribution: This paper introduces the FAINA dataset to solve the fallacy detection challenge by leveraging multilabel annotations, achieving over 11K fallacy spans labeled across different fallacy types.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically involved coarse-grained annotations or assumed the exclusivity of fallacies in a text segment.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves upon prior efforts by allowing for overlapping annotations and multiple plausible fallacy types within the same text, enhancing granularity in detection.

key_innovation: FAINA facilitates detection by embracing human label variation, making explicit the ambiguity in fallacy categorization that occurs naturally in discourse.
real_world_impact: This dataset can empower educational tools and automated systems to better analyze and counteract misinformation online, promoting critical thinking and clearer public discourse.
limitations: The dataset is limited to the Italian language, restricting applicability to broader linguistic contexts.

new_terms.fallacy detection: **Fallacy detection** refers to identifying arguments that seem logically valid but contain errors in reasoning, which can mislead audiences.
new_terms.span-level annotation: **Span-level annotation** involves labeling specific segments or sequences of text, as opposed to labeling entire documents or posts.
